Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Assessing Winter Bacterioplankton Distributions and Carbon Cycling as part of AMLR Field Program, August 2012
Award.AbstractNarration: The Southern Ocean is experiencing some of the most dramatic changes in temperature in the world, leading to marked shifts in sea ice density and cover. Research has shown that these shifts are causing major changes in the ecology of this region; however, little is known about the effects of these changes in sea ice on winter communities. This research will add a bacterioplankton sampling effort to a United States Antarctic Marine Living Resources (AMLR) winter cruise. State-of-the-art quantitative PCR, genomics techniques and bioinformatics will be used to test novel hypotheses about the role of chemolithoautotrophy in winter bacterioplankton communities. The biomass of the plankton across the AMLR survey region will also be determined, and shared with the AMLR group to generate a more comprehensive data set describing state of the winter ecosystem. Results will be widely disseminated through publication as well as through presentations at national and international meetings. In addition, raw data will be made available through open-access databases. As well, this project will contribute to the research and training of a graduate student. Finally, this work will facilitate outreach to the general public through a cruise web blog.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Picoplankton (< 3.0 micron sized plankton) include bacteria, archaea, and small single celled eukaryotes. Much of the energy in the ocean is funneled through the picoplankton where these organisms play key roles in biogeochemical cycles and serve as food for higher organisms. Picoplankton have multiple modes of energy production, some utilize light energy from the sun, others can utilize chemical energy from reduced inorganic compounds (e.g. hydrogen, ammonium), and many use the potpourri of organic carbon substrates that are produced by other organisms in the ocean. Studies that PI Murray has conducted in coastal waters off Anvers Island on the Antarctic Peninsula suggested that there is a shift from heterotroph-dominated picoplankton in Antarctic summer to waters that harbor abundant chemoautotrophic organisms in winter.   

 

This RAPID project provided the opportunity to participate in three winter oceanographic research cruises to the Antarctic Peninsula region aboard the RVIB Nathaniel B. Palmer with the U.S. Antarctic Marine Living Resources (AMLR) Ecosystem Studies Program. The AMLR program has conducted long term oceanographic surveys in this region to monitor the marine ecosystem (mostly during January) which includes thriving krill populations that support abundant top predators and a krill fishery. These cruises provided an unprecedented opportunity for Murray’s team to survey a large swath of Antarctic Peninsula and offshore waters to develop a spatial map of picoplankton abundance and community composition in winter waters in order build upon the hypothesis that chemoautotrophic organisms are abundant in winter waters, where organic carbon resources are extremely limited, yet inorganic energy sources are replete.

 

The AMLR team characterized winter marine ecosystem components to better understand the importance of winter conditions on the success of the populations (krill and top predators) the following summer. The study area encompassed open ocean waters of the Scotia Sea and west of the South Shetland Islands, and more southerly waters of Bransfield Strait and those exiting the Weddell Sea near Joinville Island. Through this synergistic collaboration with the AMLR group Murray’s team studied the physical-chemical-biological marine ecosystem and collected a large, spatially expansive data set that included vertical profiles (6 depths between 15-750 m) at 61 stations resulting in over 350 samples being collected for water chemistry, phototrophic and heterotrophic picoplankton cell abundances, DNA and RNA biomass.

 

We were fortunate to encounter three very different winter seasons in terms of sea ice cover (defined southerly ice edge, widespread sea ice through the study area and low to no sea ice) – which provided the ability to study distributions of the microbial plankton in conditions of high and low sea ice cover. These conditions also provided the opportunity to sample ice floes during the 2013 cruise. Our preliminary results support the hypothesis that chemoautotrophic archaea and potentially chemoautotrophic and/or mixotrophic bacteria comprise 40-50% of picoplankton in the waters surveyed.
